Question
column3: Answer

session_1747386819773_4s8e13v: To what extent do you support or oppose universal healthcare policies that provide government-funded healthcare coverage for all citizens? Please explain your reasoning.
column3: Fully support universal health care. Health care is a human right. And in advance, I'll be a bit blunt on these answers because on Prolific, it said that the survey should last about an hour. But it's been well over an hour, and it's very late at night, so I'm getting very tired. But explanation aside, yes, health care is a basic human right. Everyone has a right to it. It's essentially absolutely terrible to decide who deserves to live and who deserves to live well based on how much money they have or the history their family has, what kind of privilege they come from. That's about it.

session_1747386819773_4s8e13v: What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of implementing a universal healthcare system?
column3: I can't see anything negative aside from very many people are going to bitch about it, especially the rich. I suppose it's negative for the rich. Positive, it'll give people the care that they need. Basically every successful nation I can think of has universal health care. We will be following the morality of the basic principles of human rights, which is that every person deserves to live. We are not valuing life based on its financial worth, that's a positive. Those are a couple of the more significant impacts that I can see.

session_1747386819773_4s8e13v: How do you think universal healthcare policies might affect healthcare quality and accessibility?
column3: I think it would make healthcare far more accessible. There are so many people who put off seeking care who decide not to treat things when it could be life-saving otherwise because they can't afford it. It will absolutely improve accessibility. Of course, there's something to say about quality. Hospitals will need some time to adjust to everything, but once they do, it'll absolutely be beneficial. I think that once everything is put into place, it will absolutely improve quality as well. For instance, right now, quality is terrible because if you can't afford something, then you're not getting the best treatments that you could. If everyone got the treatment they needed, that's already better quality.

session_1747386819773_4s8e13v: What impact do you believe a universal healthcare system might have on medical innovation and research?
column3: I mean, I think it would be great. There would be less private insurance, less funding going to those corrupt, horrible people. I think that there would be a lot more time and money not being spent on terrible things like that to go towards actually innovating and helping and knowing what problems people have and what needs to be solved. I definitely am not as well versed on this topic. I don't know very much about medical research. I can't see it having a negative effect that more people are getting care on medical innovation. If anything, maybe we get some new case studies or maybe we'd even find some new cures to things. We'd find different people who are immune to different things and we'd be able to find the causes. There are so many different benefits to actually keeping people alive and treating them.

session_1747386819773_4s8e13v: How do you think universal healthcare might affect the economic burden on individuals and families?
column3: It would be a significant weight lifted, especially for people of lower income. I can't imagine the burden lifted. There are so many people who are in such significant medical debt. There are people who save their entire lives for retirement and then end up getting cancer and lose everything because of the cost of the treatment, even with insurance. It would be such a burden lifted. There are people who die for this every single day. Private insurance is quite literally murdering people. So the burden of not worrying that you're going to lose everything or die because you get sick is a significant burden lifted from individuals and families alike.

session_1747386819773_4s8e13v: What role do you believe government should play in healthcare delivery and financing?
column3: I mean, I'm pretty sure that that's how it should be, is that the government takes care of its people. Is that what's happening? No. Do I trust this current administration to do it? Absolutely not. But, um, I'm not entirely sure about financing. I'm pretty sure that, just, yeah, I would assume the government would be in charge of that. There would be a total subset of it to do that, and people would be voted in for it. Um, even if it were put down to, like, local governments, I'd be fine with that, as long as there's some sort of regulation, and taxpayer dollars are going towards that, and not the military. I'm fine with it, you know?

session_1747386819773_4s8e13v: How might healthcare provider concerns factor into decisions about universal healthcare implementation?
column3: I don't really fully understand what that means, health care provider concerns. I mean, I think that health care providers are in it to save lives. I guess maybe if health care providers want to make more money from private insurance, then that's not great for them. But at that point, I think we just understand who deserves to become a doctor and who's just in it for money, who's not going to take care of their patients properly. So I don't think it should very much factor into it unless potentially health care providers are worried that they won't be able to give care as well, in which case we should listen to them. I'm not a health care provider, so I don't know what concerns they would come into. I don't know if it would be positive or negative or what. So I can't really answer that in good faith or with knowledge.

session_1747386819773_4s8e13v: What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from transitioning to a universal healthcare system?
column3: I mean, again, taxes might be higher because we're paying for some sort of universal healthcare system. Um, so that would be a negative for most people. Positive, you know, maybe you wouldn't have to pay as much to survive. So on an individual basis, that's pretty great. More money can go towards local businesses or generally other things. Like it would be great for consumerism because you could actually afford to buy yourself little luxuries and not have to pay off hospital bills every month. Um, but aside from that, even facing the negative economic effects, uh, okay. More taxes. Well, a significant amount of taxes here in the U S already goes towards funding the military industrial complex, which is a huge waste. This is, it's a significant amount. I would say perhaps rather than a significant amount of our taxes going towards that they could go towards this instead, and we wouldn't even have to pay a significant amount more because taxes are already pretty up there.

session_1747386819773_4s8e13v: How do you think the interests of taxpayers versus healthcare consumers should be balanced when making healthcare policy?
column3: This is a weird question because taxpayers are health care consumers. The general public is what it is. And I don't, I mean, if the question is people who are rich talking about people who are disabled or need medical care, then of course, people who need health care should be prioritized. People have a right to live. It's already been like, you people have a right to housing. You people have a right to food. The answer is yes to all of it. But of course, people have a right to survive. People have a right to their health and to live, to live. You can't say someone deserves to die because you don't want to pay taxes. That's a disgusting, cruel thing. And people like that should not be prioritized.

session_1747386819773_4s8e13v: What role do you think social equity and access to care play in discussions about healthcare policy?
column3: A thousand percent, that's everything. The fact that you shouldn't be told you have the right to survive or not based on your equity, based on how much you have. The rich shouldn't survive just because they're rich and the poor shouldn't have to suffer or be in debt or die just because they can't afford care. That's the basis of universal health care is that everybody is equal in their right to survive. No matter what kind of person you are, no matter how much you have, no matter what you own, you have a right to survive. That's the basis of it. It's more that morality and humanity has a role in health care policy.

column3: I don't understand this question. Changes in universal health care lead to changes in support. Well yes, any changes in universal health care would lead to changes in how people feel about it, be it positive or negative. I don't know how strong the effect would be because I don't know what changes are being made to universal health care. This question doesn't make sense.

column3: It depends on what side you're on. If you believe in human rights and morals, then it would have a positive effect on support. And if you don't believe that humans have a basic right to health and survival, then they would have a negative effect. This just fully depends on the kind of person that you are. So yeah, it has an effect. It just depends on your own morality.

column3: I mean, yes, I suppose small changes in the right direction would lead to changes in support. I don't know what kind of changes they would be, if it was positive or negative changes. If we were going towards accessibility for all, then maybe people wouldn't be as persistent on universal healthcare, but that would be because things are getting better. I think that no matter what, we should be fighting for universal healthcare because rather than things getting just a little bit better, they should be equal.

I would say it has a pretty strong effect on people who believe that people are equal, yes.
